Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Air-Oxidation of Biomass Chars - Structural Changes and Implications for Retention and Reactions of Contaminants
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation. It represents a collaboration between Dr. Joseph Pignatello at the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station, Professor Klaus Schmidt-Rohr at Brandeis University, and Professor Jingdong Mao at Old Dominion University. Together with their postdocs and graduate students, they investigate properties and behavior of biomass chars in the environment. Biochar particles are partially burned plant matter with blackened surfaces. Char results from natural and deliberately-set fires and are common components of soil and aquatic sediments. Activated carbon (a form of charcoal) and biochar can be beneficial soil additives for use in agricultural processes. Important attributes of chars include their ability to strongly bind pollutant and to change the identity of the pollutant molecules. Air may be present or absent during the charring process. It is usually present during the weathering of chars in the environment. The oxygen in air can have major effects on the physical and chemical properties of chars and can impact their functions as materials that absorb and change pollutants. This research examines the absorption and change in pollutants on biochar surfaces using carefully controlled experiments at both room temperatures and higher temperatures. This project provides benefits to society by studying how biomass chars affect the fate of pollutants in the environment. It also provides valuable information that may be useful in efforts to clean up contaminated sites, as well as in agricultural applications. In addition to fostering the training of students and postdoctoral fellows, this project incorporates a visiting scholars program for PhD students and professors, an internship program for undergraduate students, an Honors College program to foster involvement of undergraduate students in active research, and mentorship programs for high school students. The project has strong outreach and education components directed at engaging prospective scientists among historically disadvantaged groups, especially at Old Dominion University, which is an urban campus with a significant minority population.

Biomass chars are ubiquitous components of soil and sediment from fires and also have attracted interest as soil amendments in agriculture and environmental remediation. Important attributes of chars include their ability to effectively adsorb organic and inorganic compounds and to mediate electron transfer reactions to/from or between organic species. Air present during or after pyrolysis can have major effects on the physical-chemical properties of chars that impact these functions, yet this subject has received
little attention. The objectives of this project are to determine the underlying structural and chemical alterations of char caused by both thermal and ambient air oxidation (AO), and to determine the effects of these alterations critical to their interactions with emerging pollutants. In the laboratory chars are made from wood and switchgrass. The test compounds are phosphate, arsenate, arsenite, selenite, aquatic herbicides (diquat and paraquat), and model organic compounds. Advanced solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is employed to identify and quantify changes in functional group composition and fused aromatic ring size. This also allows detection of signals coming from exceptionally strong hydrogen bonds formed between surface groups and weak acid adsorbates. NMR sensitivities are enhanced by using 13C-enriched switchgrass as the biomass precursor and 13C-labelled compounds as adsorbates. The project investigates the consequences of air oxidation on the formation of exceptionally strong hydrogen bonds. It also addresses cation exchange interactions, dissolved organic matter competition for adsorption sites, oxidation-reduction reactions mediated by chars, and the concentrations of persistent free radicals formed by the pyrolysis process. The findings are expected to provide novel insights for char structure and weak acid solute behavior in the environment. The project has outreach and education components and aims to engage students among historically disadvantaged groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chars are the carbonaceous byproducts of incomplete combustion of biomass in fires and thus are widely dispersed in soils and sediments. Some forms (biochars, charcoals, activated carbons) are manufactured for use in agriculture and soil/water purification. Chars undergo oxidative transformations when air is present during pyrolysis, and by abiotic or enzymatic processes during weathering in the environment. However, little is known about the specific transformations that occur and the consequences of those transformations. The objectives of this project are to determine, 1) the underlying structural and chemical alterations of char caused by thermal and ambient oxidation; and 2) effects of these alterations on the properties of chars critical to their interactions with pollutants.

Chars were made from maple, softwood, bamboo, pecan shells, and pure reference precursors, lignin and 13C isotope-enriched glucose. Samples were oxidized under thermal or ambient conditions. Thermal oxidation was carried out by concurrent pyrolysis (CPAO) or post pyrolysis (PPAO) air oxidation at different air-to-nitrogen gas levels. Ambient oxidation was carried out by repeated hydrogen peroxide addition (to mimic accelerated enzymatic weathering) or for 6 months in an atmosphere of O2 at 60 oC (to mimic accelerated chemical weathering).

Thermal oxidation results in pore reaming and incorporation of oxygen (O) atoms into the char structure. Pore reaming is enlargement of micropores and mesopores and is caused by etching of pore walls and entrained substances by the hot oxygen gas. By contrast, ambient oxidation leads to O incorporation, but not pore reaming. The O functional groups introduced were identified by advanced nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy and other techniques, and include specific ketone, ether, carboxylic, and phenolic groups. Average aromatic ring cluster size increased with pyrolysis temperature, but was otherwise unaffected by the oxidative conditions.

The physico-chemical changes of chars induced by thermal or ambient oxidation profoundly affect their interactions with organic compounds. Both adsorption and adsorption rate were generally increased by pore reaming due to creation of additional and more accessible adsorption sites. Moreover, adsorption strength (binding energy) increased with mean ring cluster size and microporosity caused by pore reaming. For example, adsorption of the aromatic hydrocarbon, naphthalene, and several perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) increased by 100-fold or more after PPAO. By contrast, incorporation of O suppresses sorption. This occurs because the polar O groups attract water molecules that “crowd out” organic molecules at adsorption sites. Both thermal and ambient oxidation increase acidic O groups, which become negatively charged near neutral pH and contribute to the char’s cation exchange capacity (CEC).  Adsorption of the dicationic aquatic herbicide, paraquat was highly sensitive to surface charge, increasing by 1000-fold as acidic groups became ionized as the pH was raised. Among a series of thermal- or ambient-oxidized chars, maximum adsorption capacity of paraquat was proportional to CEC squared, reflecting interaction of its two cationic centers with dual negative sites on the char, plus a term proportional to the adsorption capacity of naphthalene, reflecting hydrophobic effects and non-specific driving forces governing efficient packing of molecules that size in pores.

Char formation conditions affect the inherent chemical reactivity of chars. Chars freshly-prepared under anoxic conditions have about equal electron donor and acceptor capacities (EDC and EAC, respectively). Exposure to air decreases the EDC at the expense of EAC. Adsorbed substituted phenols are oxidized or reduced depending on aging history: freshly-prepared samples gave predominantly reduction products, while samples aged in air gave predominantly oxidation products. Molecular oxygen plays a triple role in char chemical reactivity: its incorporation suppresses sorption by making the surface more hydrophilic; it competes with the phenol for reducing sites on the char; and it is reduced to give H2O2, which then back-reacts with other reducing sites to produce highly-reactive hydroxyl radicals that attack the phenol.

Chars freshly prepared under anoxic conditions contain about 1019 unpaired electrons (known as persistent free radicals, PFR) per gram due to incomplete reformation of bonds during pyrolysis. The concentration of PFR declines to about half over the first month of aging to air due to reaction with O2, while the remainder is indefinitely persistent. Some PFR may be involved in reactions of char with organic compounds, but their contribution has not been confidently established.

Pyrolysis conditions during char formation favor generation of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) which are linked to cancer, cardiovascular disease, and developmental impacts. Thermal oxidation (PPAO) reduces the native PAH content of biochars and the PAH Relative Potency Factor, an EPA index to indicate health risk of mixtures.

The findings of this project have important implications for the mobility and chemical reactivity of organic compounds in the environment and for tailoring carbonaceous adsorbents for safety and efficacy in remediation or stabilization of contaminated soils. Advancements in the use of solid-state NMR techniques for characterizing chars has transferrable benefits for characterizing other complex and environmental organic materials.
